attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of Fipronil and Imidacloprid in flea treatments for pets
attributes.background: The UK Government must prohibit the manufacture, sale and use of flea treatments for domestic pets that contain harmful pesticides, in order to prevent harm to aquatic life and to protect the natural environment.
attributes.additional_details:
There are an estimated 10 million dogs and 11 million cats in the UK. 

The majority of pets routinely receive flea treatments, many of which contain toxic chemicals that find their way into watercourses, polluting rivers and poisoning aquatic life.

Fipronil and Imidacloprid - two of the chemicals most commonly used - have already been banned in farming.

The continued use of these chemicals to treat domestic pets can harm aquatic life and other organsims and must be stopped immediately.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban production and export of pesticides already banned for use within the UK
attributes.background: The UK is Europe’s biggest exporter of pesticides banned for use in the EU. An Unearthed and Public Eye investigation found that the UK exports 32,188 tonnes of banned pesticides (almost 40% of the total from the EU) and that much ends up in poorer countries like South Africa, Ukraine, and Brazil.
attributes.additional_details: We cannot allow chemical manufacturers within the UK to profit from the production and export of banned pesticides. Chemicals have been banned for use within the UK due to potential health hazards like reproductive failure, endocrine disruption or cancer, and environmental hazards like groundwater contamination or poisoning of fish, birds, mammals or bees. The Government should ensure such chemicals are not produced in the UK or exported from the UK to other countries.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund a universal income by taxing environmentally damaging products
attributes.background: Introduces 'sin taxes' (like those on tobacco and alcohol) to environmentally damaging products and services, eg. single use plastics, harmful chemicals, fertilizers and pesticides, meat and dairy, polluting transportation, etc. The money raised is then given back to everyone via a universal income.
attributes.additional_details: Environmentally friendly options are often expensive. If we make the alternatives products pay for the damage they cause, there will be a level playing field.  Prices will rise, but affordability will not be an issue as people will be in receipt of a universal income to compensate. Those who switch to a more environmentally friendly lifestyle and those on low incomes will benefit most, funded by environmentally unfriendly people and those on higher incomes.

attributes.action: Require period products list all materials/chemical/ingredients on packaging
attributes.background: We want the Government to require that all period products include a full list of all materials, chemicals and ingredients in the product. This way people can make informed decisions on what product to use.
attributes.additional_details: Manufacturers are required to to evaluate the safety of raw materials, finished product and instructions for use, but we believe this is insufficient and that manufacturers are NOT sufficiently interested in the adverse effects that their products may cause. We should have a right to know what we are putting inside our bodies to make informed choices on use.

departments.name: Department of Health and Social Care

attributes.action: Require companies using animal-tested ingredients to declare this on products
attributes.background: Require by law that cosmetics companies who commission the testing of ingredients on animals must declare on their products that the ingredients have been 'tested on animals'.
attributes.additional_details: Whilst it is illegal to test cosmetic products on animals in the UK, some cosmetics companies have been actively involved in organising & funding safety testing research for REACH (Registration, Evaluation, Authorisation and Restriction of Chemicals) which in some cases has included commissioning new animal tests. Consumers should be made aware of the companies & products that have used ingredients tested on animals after a cut-off date.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Introduce a ban on the most polluting fibres in fashion by 2025
attributes.background: Last year, 4.2bn items of clothing were sold in the UK. The majority made from conventional cotton, generic viscose and virgin polyester; fibres with a huge carbon footprint. How is this allowed at a time of climate emergency? We’re calling on the government to ban the most polluting fibres by 2025.
attributes.additional_details: Fashion accounts for 10% of global CO2 emissions yet is unregulated. A main factor is usage of conventional cotton, generic viscose and virgin polyester - fibres produced using vast amounts of pesticides, chemicals, water and fossil fuels. We need regulation fast. A ban is easy to enact and 4 years reasonable time to transition to eco-friendlier alternatives. The result; a significant reduction in CO2 emissions, soil- and water pollution, and a tangible positive impact on the planet.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban formaldehyde in motorhome/caravan toilet fluid products
attributes.background: Some blue toilet chemicals contain formaldehyde, a known human carcinogen. The government should ban the use of formaldehyde in motorhome/caravan toilet fluids because safer alternatives (including 100% natural products) are now commercially available.
attributes.additional_details:
Formaldehyde is a highly toxic systemic poison that is absorbed well by inhalation. The vapour is a severe respiratory tract and skin irritant and may cause dizziness or suffocation. Contact with formaldehyde solution may cause severe burns to the eyes and skin.

Fomaldehyde-based toilet fluids are unsuitable for all campsites with septic tanks and can seriously damage the natural environment if spilled.

We should not be allowing the use of such a dangerous ingredient in blue toilet fluids.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban all single-use plastic
attributes.background: Ban the use of single-use plastic for good.
attributes.additional_details:
While it floats and degrades, the plastic leaches marine-toxic chemicals into the water. The effects of plastic bags and bottle caps on seabirds, turtles, seals, whales and other species is graphically illustrated by their deaths from starvation after mistakenly consuming the plastic or from getting tangled up in it.

Not to mention it's never used again!

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban the selling and manufacturing of disposable vape pens
attributes.background: We are trying to be a greener planet and reduce are waist and stop single use plastics. These vape pens are only adding to the problem. They are they a single use plastic they contain single use batteries which this a resource needed to be saved for important thing that will help to save the planet.
attributes.additional_details: Disposable pens are designed to be used for one day then you buy another one. So if one person uses this product every day for a year (365 vape pens) leads to tones of plastics ending up in landfill with all the chemicals in the battery’s leaking into the ground Bring in a law to stop the pointless manufacturing of products that are only designed to be used ones and then thrown away when there are already products out there that do the same job and can be repaired, recharged and used again.

attributes.action: Ban PFAS in food packaging and seek to remove them from water supplies
attributes.background: I want you to protect our citizens. As our government it is your responsibility to protect the people. I am asking you to stop PFAS being used in supermarket and other food packaging, and explore what action can be taken to remove or reduce their concentration in water supplies.
attributes.additional_details: PFAS are known to be toxic and linked to cancer and many more life-threatening problems. They’re known as ‘forever chemicals’. Ban supermarkets from using them in packaging and stop them from being in the water we all drink. It’s your responsibility to do something about it.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale and use of Rodenticides
attributes.background: I would like the Government to ban the sale and use of rodenticides. There is evidence of secondary poisoning of other species from the consumption of the target species that has ingested the rodenticide.
attributes.additional_details: Rodenticides are causing the deaths of other species of birds and mammals, caused by the consumption of prey which has ingested a rodenticide. Toxins from the chemical brodifacoum for example build up causing a slow, suffering death. The use of rodenticides is not target specific enough and can cause wider lethal implications to other animals in the environment. We believe the sale and use of these products should be banned.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Fund the planting of wildflowers along all public green spaces
attributes.background: We would like the Government pledge funding to plant a 1-meter wide strip of wildflowers along the length of every public green space (i.e. playing fields, grass verges etc). Councils would be allocated a grant to achieve this target. The target would be set by the Government.
attributes.additional_details:
The data shows the UK has experienced extinctions and declines in abundance, biomass and distribution of insects. Declines in abundance or distribution have been seen in bees and hoverflies, butterflies and moths, beetles, and freshwater insects. There are a variety of drivers behind insect decline, such as habitat loss, chemical use and climate change, and their impacts differ across habitat, species and time.
 
Source: UK Insect Decline and Extinctions, UK Parliament POST https://researchbriefings.files.parliament.uk/documents/POST-PN-0619/POST-PN-0619.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of gift wrap that is non-recyclable.
attributes.background: Please ban gift wrap that contains elements that are no recyclable, I.e glitter, foil and plastic.
attributes.additional_details:
We need to take steps to protect harmful products from ending up as landfill and from chemicals used in these products effecting the environment. 

Banning these types of non-recyclable gift wraps is a small and important step.

departments.name: Department for Business, Energy and Industrial Strategy

attributes.action: Ban cigarettes - The Largest Ocean Polluter
attributes.background: In April 2021 England will officially ban the single use plastics such as straws and cotton buds. Wales will also do the same in Spring 2021. However the largest source of single use plastic pollution is cigarettes. Therefore it would be appropriate to also ban cigarettes.
attributes.additional_details: The Government have agreed to ban single use plastic in 2021, however the list of items banned crucially misses out cigarettes. Cigarettes are the top single use plastic polluter in the world! On top of the plastic and microplastics issue, cigarettes also add harmful chemicals such as nicotine, lead and arsenic into the environment. These chemicals enter our food chain leading to bioaccumulation. They have also been shown to inhibit plant growth on land and reduce crop yeilds.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the sale of petrol powered garden tools to encourage shift to alternatives
attributes.background: With the world in the grips of an environmental crisis there is absolutely no excuse for the continued use of garden tools that pollute the atmosphere with chemicals and noise, damage people's health, and perpetuate our reliance on fossil fuels.
attributes.additional_details:
Petrol machinery produces airborne pollution that can impair breathing & aggravate existing heart & lung conditions.
 
The US Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) has estimated that a lawnmower can produce the same air pollution as 11 cars. A Swedish study has also found that the emissions from a petrol mower used for one hour are equivalent to those released by a car on a 100-mile journey.
 
A ban on the sale of petrol powered garden tools would encourage a shift to battery powered garden tools. This should improve air quality and could help tackle global warming.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Ban the use of PAVA Spray in UK prisons following its proven misuse in pilots
attributes.background: This petition calls for the UK government to ban the use of PAVA Spray following its proven misuse on prisoners during trials.
attributes.additional_details:
Additionally we are calling for the Ministry of Justice to publish any safeguarding or training procedures relating to the use of the Section 5 weapon.
PAVA Spray-a chemically concentrated version of pepper spray has been a controversial deterrent due to its £2m rollout expense and its proven misuse in pilot trials. An analysis by the Prison Reform Trust (PRT) found that:
24% of case studies involved unsafe use of PAVA
34% of cases PAVA was used without justification
24% involved use where alternative methods were available. Not as a “last resort” - which is the only acceptable time to be used according to the Ministry of Justice.

attributes.action: Ban export of UK-manufactured pesticides which are banned from use in the UK
attributes.background: We want the UK Government to put an end to the export of UK-manufactured paraquat and other toxic pesticides. These are chemicals banned for use in the UK and 50 other countries due to the immense risks they pose to human health and the environment. The double-standard must end now.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2018 the UK Government permitted the export of over 32,000 tonnes of UK-manufactured banned pesticides, 87% of which are reported to have contained paraquat. With paraquat “one sip can kill”, and evidence is mounting of its numerous long-term health impacts.
 
Studies suggest that almost half of these pesticide exports were sent to low and middle-income countries with far weaker safety regulations. It is irresponsible to assume that these chemicals will be used safely, and it is resulting in countless predictable and preventable deaths.

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Legislate to ban commercial wooden pallets treated with highly toxic chemicals
attributes.background: We ask the Government to ban all commercial wooden pallets which are treated with highly toxic chemicals. There are other eco-friendly pallets available, and there is no justification why any industry should still be using these wooden pallets for logistical transport and distribution.
attributes.additional_details:
People may think wooden pallets are safe to burn domestically, but PM2.5 emissions are one of the most dangerous pollutants to human health. Banning wooden pallets treated with toxic chemicals should benefit the environment, public health and NHS.

More for information see the links below:

https://www.blf.org.uk/sites/default/files/Ambient%20air%20pollution_levelling%20up%20lung%20health.pdf

https://www.london.gov.uk/sites/default/files/pm2.5_in_london_october19.pdf

departments.name: Department for Environment, Food and Rural Affairs

attributes.action: Min. 10-year sanctions on Russia if chemical/biological weapons used in Ukraine
attributes.background: We want the Government to commit to keeping current and future sanctions on Russia in place for at least 10 years, if they make use of any chemical or biological weapons in Ukraine. The Government should also urge other nations to make similar commitments.
attributes.additional_details: Commitments to long-term sanctions should make clear to Russia the consequences of deploying chemical or biological weapons in Ukraine.

attributes.action: Restore the ban on Neonicotinoids.
attributes.background:
Follow the Wildlife Trusts report on Reversing the Decline of Insects in the UK, starting with restoring the ban on Neonicotinoids.
Tough new standards should be introduced on the use of pesticides, and support should be put in place to help farmers follow insect friendly practices.
attributes.additional_details: Only the Government has the power to ban the use of these chemicals in the UK, and the Tory manifesto promised not only support for the environment, but support for British farmes too. This is something that can do both of those at once.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Protect bees: Revoke the license for Neonicotinoid pesticide use.
attributes.background: The Health and Safety Executive have granted an application from NFU Sugar and British Sugar seeking emergency authorisation for the use of a neonicotinoid product as a seed treatment on sugar beet. These chemicals reduce bee colony viability. The Government should ban their use in line with EU laws
attributes.additional_details: It's been known for years that neonicotinoid pesticides interfere with the brain behaviour of bees. Bees are already under threat from other forms of colony collapse disorder yet they are a vital asset to the economy as they provide a free but critical service to our agriculture industry. Without them our food and agriculture system would be brought to it's knees putting dependant ecosystems at risk of collapse.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Stop the Government from letting farmers use bee-killing neonicotinoids
attributes.background: Neonicotinoid pesticides, which kill bees, are still allowed to be used in the UK for emergency purposes. We want the government to completely ban this toxic chemical in order to protect our declining bee population and raise environmental standards.
attributes.additional_details: Several study’s have found a connection between higher levels of neonicotinoid residues and lower bee reproduction, with a reduced number of queen bees in bumblebee hives and less egg cells in solitary bee nests. In 2018 the EU agreed a ban on all outdoor uses of three neonicotinoid insecticides to protect bees. However since 2018, multiple emergency uses of the pesticide have been allowed in the EU. In January 2021 the uk government granted emergency use in the UK. We call for a total ban.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Ban the manufacturing, sale, and import of disposable vape pens in the UK
attributes.background: 168 million disposable vape pens are sold annually in the UK, with a significant number of discarded vapes not even making it to landfill; they are increasingly found in our streets, rivers, and seas, where they pose a threat to our ecosystem. As they gain popularity, the issue will get worse.
attributes.additional_details: Not only do vapes contain plastic, but also   metals in the battery and heating element, including 0.15g of lithium. Lithium can be toxic to wildlife, and there is evidence that both domestic and wild animals are attracted to chemicals found in vapes, which animals will seek out and chew with potentially lethal outcomes. Lithium is also rare, and is a vital component for batteries which are used for more useful devices, such as laptops and mobile phones. We should not be wasted it in vapes.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/628115

attributes.action: Maintain the UK ban on bee-harming pesticides and use of Neonicotinoids
attributes.background: We ask the government to maintain the ban on on all outdoor uses of the neonicotinoid Thiamethoxam. This is proven to be harmful to bees and other wildlife.  We need safeguards to prevent the pollution of run off water containing the chemical at a time when British insects are in serious decline.
attributes.additional_details:
In 2018 Michael Gove, then the environment secretary, said: “The weight of evidence now shows the risks neonicotinoids pose to our environment, particularly to the bees and other pollinators which play such a key part in our £100bn food industry, is greater than previously understood… We cannot afford to put our pollinator populations at risk.”
He also wrote in the Guardian: “Unless the evidence base changes again, the government will keep these restrictions in place after we have left the EU.”

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Legalise human composting in the UK and make this eco-friendly option available
attributes.background: To give bereaved families an eco-friendly end of life alternative to burial or cremation. The human composting process is a natural process which avoids the use of any chemicals or fuels and results in rich, fertile soil being returned to the family.
attributes.additional_details: Burial and cremation are currently the only funeral options available to bereaved families in the UK. Both of these options are extremely harmful to the environment. Over 75% of families opt for a cremation which is approximately 470,000 cremations a year. Each cremation produces on average 250kgs of carbon dioxide which is released into the atmosphere (that's 115,000 tonnes a year) Burial also has its own list of harmful factors. One being the absorption of harmful chemicals into earth.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/624352

attributes.action: Danger of soil extinction is grave - Save our Soil Biodiversity / Insect Biomass
attributes.background: UN says 1/3rd of the world's soil already degraded. Only 60 years of agricultural soil left. Journal of Biological Conservation says 80% of Insect Biomass lost in last 30 years. We caused this suicide and we must fix it. The government must introduce policies to rejuvenate and revitalize our soil.
attributes.additional_details: UN says soil is a very significant carbon sink linked to climate change; being the largest water soak on the planet and basis of all lives. Our wellbeing is not separate from the wellbeing of the soil. It is a very significant ecological threat as the way we grow food must change. The government must enforce policies that produces food in an organic way and stop using commercial and chemical fertilizers on our soil. Instead produce organic fertilizers using plants and animals waste themselves.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about degradation of soil, but we're not sure exactly what you'd like the Government or Parliament to do.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do. For example, we could accept a petition calling on the Government to ban certain fertilisers, or to publish a strategy for preventing the degradation of soil quality, if either of those are something you want to happen.

attributes.action: Products must have warning labels if they contain harmful toxic chemicals.
attributes.background: The products we use everyday could have harmful toxic chemicals that could be destroying our health every single day. Exposure to toxic  chemicals such as Bisphenol A (BPA) and Phthalates could cause problems with the reproductive system. Therefore we must know about what  chemicals are in products.
attributes.additional_details:
https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7071371/

https://www.google.com/amp/s/amp.cancer.org/cancer/cancer-causes/formaldehyde.html

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC7530144/

https://www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/pmc/articles/PMC6396757/

rejection.details:
Suppliers are already required to label hazardous goods, so we're not clear what it is you'd like the Government to do. 

Decisions on which materials should be classed as hazardous are the responsibility of the Health and Safety Executive (HSE), not the UK Government or Parliament. You can find out more about this here: https://www.hse.gov.uk/chemical-classification/labelling-packaging/index.htm

You could start a petition calling for manufacturers to be required to label each individual hazardous component on goods available to the public, if that is something you'd like to see happen.

attributes.action: Ban the use of Neonicotinoid Pesticides in order to protect bees
attributes.background:
Bees are major pollinators and vital to our eco system.
We have lost a third of our bee population and up to 50% of other insects in recent years.
The Government banned the use of Neonicotinoids in 2018 because of this, but now appears to have back-tracked on this wise policy.
attributes.additional_details:
Mr Eustice plans to allow the use of this chemical in sugar beet production, treating the seeds to prevent the spread of a virus in the crop. However, this will cause a significant risk to bees and other pollinators. 

Neonicotinoid pesticides should therefore be banned permanently, and not used even in the "limited and controlled" way proposed by the Environment Secretary.

rejection.details:
You might like to sign the following petitions:

Overturn the decision to allow the use of neonicotinoid pesticides
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/569214

Continue the ban on the use of Neonicotinoids
https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/563943

attributes.action: Ban the manufacture and sale of disposable vapes
attributes.background: Allowing the manufacture and sale of disposable vapes is undermining national targets to reduce the amount of chemicals and plastics entering the environment. Government must work urgently with manufacturers and retailers to ban the manufacture and sale of disposable vapes to protect the environment
attributes.additional_details:
Disposable vapes contain lithium batteries, metal wiring and plastic parts. 

Carelessly discarded vapes now litter the UK and pose a choking hazard to wildlife. The batteries pose a fire hazard and leach toxic chemicals into the environment. 

Research suggests that people in the UK are throwing away approximately two disposable vapes every second, resulting in 10 tonnes of lithium being sent to landfill every year.

Lithium is a precious metal that is used in electric cars and solar panels.

rejection.details: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/628115

attributes.action: Ban Single-Use Electronic Cigarettes.
attributes.background: They are made of plastic and a hazardous lithium-ion battery These chemicals are extremely hazardous to the environment and wildlife. The batteries are also fully rechargeable. they are simply designed without a power connection to render them obsolete after 24 hours use.
attributes.additional_details: It is very contradictory against the green agenda that is going on at the moment. Citizens are being told to work more hours and take shorter showers when corporations are being allowed to profit from this kind of plastic and chemical waste destined for landfill and the ground. Look around on any street and you will see these devices on the ground. often with their batteries hanging out. These batteries have potential years of use in them. designing them to be disposed of so quickly is immoral.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for the same action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/612333

attributes.action: RESTRICT THE USE OF FIREWORKS SO THEY ARE ONLY USED BONFIRE NIGHT AND NEW YEARS
attributes.background:
Stop the use of fireworks for birthdays, weddings etc
To let Fireworks only be used at relevant times of the year for BONFIRE night and NEW YEARS EVE only.
attributes.additional_details:
Even with their ephemeral nature, fireworks cause a lot of air pollution in a very short amount of time. ... A scientist told Forbes that when the fireworks go off, the metal salts and explosives undergo a chemical reaction that releases smoke and gases into the air.  As we are fighting to protect our ozone I feel that fireworks are adding to the problem of air pollution.
They only used to be used bonfire night and from 2000 new years eve.
It is also causing great stress to pets at home.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition calling for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/595560

attributes.action: Ban the use of Per - and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) in UK food packaging.
attributes.background: There is strong evidence that Perfluoroalkyl and Polyfluoroalkyl Substances (PFAS) are found in UK food packaging. There are extensive studies that show these "forever chemicals" are an immanent threat to public health. They should be banned from manufacturing, like the global ban on the use of PFOA
attributes.additional_details:
The UK Government must commit to joining this phase-out of PFAS.
A growing body of science has found that there are potential adverse health impacts associated with PFAS exposure, including liver damage, thyroid disease, decreased fertility, high cholesterol, obesity, hormone suppression and cancer. 

Non-stick pans, furniture, cosmetics, household cleaners, clothing, and packaged food containers can all contain PFCs, many of which break down into PFOA in the environment or in the human body.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about PFAs, but we're not sure if you want the Government to ban their use in food packaging, or all manufacturing.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: current circumstances hasn’t this made you realise we need our local farmers
attributes.background: I think as a nation we need to support British farmers more on a whole and make all / most meats in our uk stores our nation own.we as British farmers have high animal wealth fare standards and a lot of countries want our standards.why don’t we support them? Before it’s to late support British
attributes.additional_details: Support our products let them be know for how amazing they are we use our farmers Service everyday 3 times a day if not more.asda and Sainsbury’s buy imports from Poland all the transport is bad if we supported Britain their would be this travelling and we would know that our animal that we are eating is good quality and has been treated well and hasn’t been injected with chemicals support Britain today and get trustworthy meat.

If you want the Government to take other measures, such as increasing subsidies for UK farmers, or imposing tariffs on agricultural imports, you could start a new petition requesting this.

attributes.action: Commission independent studies on the safety and need for Eco Engineering.
attributes.background: The chemicals used during Eco Engineering operations enter our air, food and water and are suspected to be causing melting of the ice caps. We require independent studies to undertake risk assessments to verify that these chemicals are safe to all living things and will not  damage the environment.
attributes.additional_details: There has been massive controversy regarding the use of Eco Engineering operations and major concerns regarding safety remain. Studies to verify safe use must be commissioned as soon as possible to enable independent bodies with no conflicts of interest to allay public fears once and for all.

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you're concerned about the potential impact of certain activities, but we're note sure exactly what you mean by "Eco Engineering operations".

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what activities you would like the Government to commission research into.

attributes.action: No direct military confrontation with Russia in Ukraine
attributes.background: The government must avoid any direct military confrontation with Russia in Ukraine, even if more destructive weapons are used. It should stick to the red line of defending NATO nations. This petition rejects the imposition of any no-fly zone in Ukraine or the sending of NATO troops.
attributes.additional_details: Any proportional response to escalation by Russia in Ukraine (eg the Russian use of chemical weapons) would risk a nuclear exchange, the start of World War 3 and devastation that goes way beyond anything during the war in Ukraine. The government should seek to minimise any risk of nuclear war with Russia. We note the paranoia of Vladimir Putin, his autocratic leadership, and that the west did not respond militarily to the Soviet invasions of Hungary in 1956 or Czechoslovakia in 1968.

rejection.details: You may wish to sign this petition which calls for a similar action: https://petition.parliament.uk/petitions/609596

attributes.action: Make it illegal to breed, import, sell or provide dogs for vivisection.
attributes.background: There is evidence that results of animal testing are unreliable for humans and opponents want an inquiry by independent experts. Some say it is simply cruel. The Great Apes have been exempted since 1986. We think dogs should also be exempted and should not be bred especially for this purpose.
attributes.additional_details: Dogs are "specially protected" when being experimented upon; however, they are not protected from having tubes stuck into their bodies while toxic chemicals are pumped into them to measure the effects on their various internal organs. The vast majority of dogs used in this way, both worldwide and in British laboratories, are beagles and breeding them for toxicity tests is very lucrative. One company alone breeds 2,000 beagle pups a year and distributes them throughout the UK. It must stop.

attributes.action: Ban All Lethal “Pest” Control in Favour of Sterilisation
attributes.background:
I have been reading about the development and potential use of a chemical in New York, USA, that renders rats sterile. This could be a new, more humane, non-lethal way to control rats!
 Rats just want to live well. They and other “pest” animal’s shouldn’t be killed by lethal traps or poison!
attributes.additional_details: At the moment, possibly millions (or more) innocent animals like rats, mice, pigeons, foxes, crows and rabbits are killed unjustly simply because their interests clash with those of humans. They don’t deliberately set out to be a problem to us or spread diseases; they just want to live and live well! We don’t need to cohabit with these animals; all we need to do is respect their right to live and deal with them in humane and non-lethal ways...

rejection.details:
Petitions need to call on the Government or Parliament to take a specific action.

We understand that you are concerned about lethal methods of pest control, but we're not sure if you just want lethal methods of pest control to be banned, or if you only want pest control methods involving sterilisation to be permitted. There are a wide range of non-lethal methods for controlling some pests.

You could start a new petition explaining clearly what you would like the Government or Parliament to do.

attributes.action: Ban fipronil and imidacloprid from pet flea products as they kill river insects
attributes.background: One flea treatment contains enough pesticide to kill 60 million bees! The washing of pets flushes chemicals into rivers, while dogs swimming is another pathway for contamination. Rivers are being polluted. The government is requested to ban the use of these products in all pet flea treatments.
attributes.additional_details: Almost 4,000 samples recently gathered by the Environment Agency in 20 English rivers showed Fipronil was detected in 99% of samples and a highly toxic breakdown product called fipronil sulfone was found in 97%. The average concentrations were 5 and 38 times higher than their chronic toxicity limits, respectively. Imidacloprid was found in 66% of the samples and was above toxicity limits in seven of the 20 rivers.  Many pets are treated every month, whether needed or not.

attributes.action: Reduce plastic waste in the oceans and limit it in everyday life
attributes.background: The UK produces five million tonnes of plastic every year. Only 9% of all global plastic is recycled. This needs to be changed. 88% of our ocean's surface is plastic, and that's bound to increase if we don't narrow down our plastic use and stop dumping it into the oceans.
attributes.additional_details: Plastic has been found in more than 60% of all seabirds and 100% of all sea turtle species, who mistake the plastics for food (Ocean Conservancy). It is estimated that 1.1 to 8.8 million tonnes of plastic waste enter our oceans each year (Wikipedia). Not to mention that many chemicals used to make plastic are known to be carcinogenic and interfere with the body's hormones causing reproductive, neurological and immune disorders in both humans and wildlife. These figures need to be changed.

attributes.action: Ban the sale of petrol powered garden tools with a view to phasing out their use
attributes.background: With the world in the grips of an environmental crisis, and a wide range of alternative technology available, there is absolutely no excuse for the continued use of garden tools that pollute the atmosphere with chemicals and noise, damage people's health and perpetuate our reliance on fossil fuels.
attributes.additional_details:
The Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) estimates that, around the world, more fuel is lost when filling lawnmowers & other garden equipment every year than the oil that was lost in the Exxon Valdez disaster.
Petrol machinery also produces a variety of airborne pollutants that can impair breathing & aggravate existing heart & lung conditions.
A Swedish study has also found that the emissions from a petrol mower used for one hour are equivalent to those released by a car on a 100-mile journey.

attributes.action: Legalise 'natural organic reduction' (human composting).
attributes.background: Human composting would add a natural ecologically friendly funerary option that enables a person to return to, and renourish the soil from which we all came.
attributes.additional_details:
Current options of burial (chop down a tree, pump you full chemicals, take up valuable space in a cemetery) and cremation (using over 100 litres of fuel to incinerate you at over 600C releasing of 220kg of CO2)  are environmentally damaging.
Natural organic reduction gradually breaks down a body over a 30-50 day period resulting in compost that can be used in rebuilding or regenerating woods and forests or simply in your back garden.

rejection.details:
It is already possible to be buried in a green burial site. Find out more here: https://www.gov.uk/guidance/cemeteries-and-burials-prevent-groundwater-pollution#green-burial-sites

If you want the Government to change rules around green burials you could start a new petition stating clearly how you want existing rules to be changed.
